Stock market 

 A network of stock exchanges where traders and investors buy and sell shares of publicly-traded companies. 
 
 Private company 

 A company is typically owned by a small number of investors (usually consisting of people like you, your friends or parents, and professional investors) ⇒ large companies can stay private too. 
 
 Once the company goes public, you’re opening up that business to be owned by a large number of people. Initial public offering (IPO) is the first time a company sells shares of stock to the public. 
 
 This means that a company that was privately-owned until then becomes a publicly-traded company 
 
 
 So why go public? 

 Going public raises a lot of cash for a company; with that money, it becomes easier for a company to grow.
 

Why invest? 

 Buying stocks makes the investor (you) partial owner of that business.
